data.title: Search in folder with special characters `{}` yields no results.
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Version 1.7.2 (1.7.2) - 7ba55c5860b152d999dda59393ca3ebeb1b5c85f
- OS Version: Mac OS X El Capitan 10.11.6 

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Create folder called `{hello}`
2. Place `hello.txt file` in folder with `hello`
3. Click `{hello}/` in sidebar to "Find in Folder" `hello`
> This inputs `{hello}` in the "files to include" input of the Search bar.
4. *Observe* that no results are found.

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2925395/20977078/05976918-bc6a-11e6-98c0-c7a94dac6f7f.png)

data.title: Keybinding service should not dispatch on modifier keys
data.body:
Have the following keybinding:
```
{
	"key": "ctrl+<",
	"command": "workbench.action.reloadWindow",
	"when": "editorTextFocus"
}
```

Press `ctrl`. Notice the workbench reloading.

Found in https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/16539#issuecomment-265126973

data.body: Extracted from last bullet point of @aeschli in #16627

data.title: fixes #10481
Support to show "unassigned" keybindings in the release notes editor
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.8.0 Insiders
- OS Version: Windows 10

Unlike the website key binding rendering which returns "unassigned" for missing command key bindings, the in-product rendering simply returns the command id string.  To workaround this, we've been manually setting the key binding to "unassigned" in Markdown. This is a poor workaround when a key binding exists for some platforms (ex. Linux) but not others.

Perhaps getKeybindingLabel() could be changed to return "unassigned" instead of 0 for missing key bindings. Note that getKeybindingLabel() is used through out the product so care should be taken that a change doesn't cause a regression somewhere else.

data.title: Hot exit: automatically restored window has lowercase workspace path
data.body:
MacOS

- Dirty a file
- Quit vscode
- Open some other folder with vscode so that the orginal workspace is opened
- The original workspace will have a lowercase workspace path - if you hover a file to see its full path, it will be all lowercase.

This causes problems with debugging - https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/16570

data.title: Save password for ssh connection to git
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.7.2
- OS Version: Windows 7

I am trying to authenticate against my git repo through PuTTY. This type of url: ssh://localhost:8889/myRepo.git
I have to supply a username and password but in vscode I don't get any prompt I just get this error in the git output:
```
git fetch
Permission denied, please try again
Permission denied, please try again (publickey, password, keyboard-interactive)
fatal: Could not read from remote repository.
Please make sure you have the correct acces rights and the repository exists.
```
To work around this I had to use something like SourceTree since here I could save the username and password for the repo in the authentication tab in this program.

I figgured out that if I type this line in git I get a popup window when I open vscode where I can enter the password for the repo but there is no option here to save the password so I have to retype the password on every interaction that vscode does to git (which is alot)
`git config --global credential.helper wincred  `

Is there any solution for fixing this so I can save the password?

data.title: Hot Exit: Very difficult to get out of a bad search/replace
data.body:
Testing #16544

* create a file `generator.js`
```js
var fs = require('fs');

for (var i = 0; i < 200; i++) {
	fs.writeFileSync('consumer_'+i+'.ts', `
import {x} from './provider';

console.log(x);
`)
}

fs.writeFileSync('provider.ts', `
export var x = 'Hello world';
`)
```
* run `node generator.js`
* open the folder where you have generated these files
* do a search for `x` whole words, case sensitive, `*.ts` files only
* replace everything with `y`
* run the replace
* close VS Code
* open VS Code
* the files are restored and **slowly** dots are appearing next to the file names. (why slowly?)
* try to close all the files (via right click close all, or via the close all editors action in the explorer)
> You get prompted for each and every one. This is a regression IMHO since in the stable version there is a single dialog that prompts me for all 200+ files:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5047891/20972759/3b5fb326-bc96-11e6-89be-6708900f94f1.png)

data.title: Regroup view menu
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.8.0 - insider 7499a9f
- OS Version: Windows 10

-- Sorry for the English, I used Google Translator --

Steps to Reproduce:

1. For a resolution of 1366 x 768 the view menu is getting too big, getting out of position.

2. I think it would be possible to group some menu items with a generic name and a side menu (with an arrow) to show the items (if I'm not wrong, the name is Submenu). As in `File> Open Recent>`, `File> Preferences>`, `Go> Switch Editor>`, `Go> Switch Group>`.

3. Or create a new menu in the Bar Menu by relocating some items.

![capturar](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/19866231/20972496/256de890-bc7c-11e6-8222-0a40fb412090.JPG)

- OS Version: Windows10

I want option which is to open definition part on the another tab. It is useful when there are large files.
If it is the current implementation, it will move in the same file. 
So, I often do not know where the original place was.

data.title: Hot Exit: Editor view state is not restored
data.body:
Testing #16544

* run `code-insiders notes2.txt` where `notes2.txt` does not exist on disk
* type something in it
* close the window
* start Code Insiders from the taskbar
* switch from the Untitled file to `notes2.txt`
> Observe: cursor position is at (1;1), the scroll state, the folding regions, etc. are not maintained.

data.title: Hot Exit: opens needless untitled file when restoring backups
data.body:
Testing #16544

(Maybe related to #16820), but this is about the Untitled file.

* run `code-insiders notes.txt`, where `notes.txt` does not exist on disk
* type something
* close the window
* launch VS Code Insiders from the taskbar

> It shows an untitled file for a split second, then `notes.txt` opens in a separate tab (in the background). I would expect it to start up and immediately show `notes.txt`, since that is the last file I had opened/typed in/left unsaved:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5047891/20970975/0312f722-bc90-11e6-9455-b4589dcf09f5.png)

data.title: Hot Exit: Opens the same file twice in two separate windows
data.body:
Testing #16544

* have a file `fileA.txt` that is empty
* run `code-insiders fileA.txt`
* type `asdasd`
* the file is dirty
* close the window
* run `code-insiders fileA.txt`
> Two instances of VS Code appear, both showing `fileA.txt` and one of them also showing an untitled editor. This behaviour is very surprising to me.

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5047891/20970308/3ba89388-bc8d-11e6-9065-179d0858df05.png)

data.title: Compile errors in the editor
data.body:
Since today (Insiders-1.8.0 0d65ced0fa7398dc9d50c39a23a2a8cc8406ff18) I see compile errors in the editor that don't show up when running `gulp watch`. Unsure if this is new TypeScript behaviour or bugs? Samples are

* https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/master/src/vs/workbench/api/node/extHostConfiguration.ts#L110
* https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/master/src/vs/editor/contrib/snippet/common/snippetParser.ts#L208

data.title: View: Rename View Menu Item
data.body:
Testing #16783 

Should we name the context menu `Additional Views` vs `Additional Viewlets`

I'm not massively passionate but it may make more sense to the user i.e. viewlet is to some degree our own internal language vs the way we show it in the menu or the command palette.

For instace we in this image we use the word `view bar` so it fells like it would be more consistent.
![codebasics_hero](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1051190/20969262/197728ce-bc3d-11e6-8894-27ba30134e44.png)

data.title: registerTextEditorCommand doesn't wait for promises to finish
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.7.2
- OS Version: Mac and Linux but should affect all OSs

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Create a new extension
2. Register a command using `registerTextEditorCommand`
3. Use `showInputBox` inside the callback
4. The callback returns before the end of the `showInputBox`

The command doesn't wait for the promise to finish.

Shouldn't `registerTextEditorCommand` return a `T | Thenable<T>` just like its **big brother** `registerCommand`, or am I doing something wrong?

data.title: css syntax highlight is broken for @supports
Explorer Should have a horizontal scroll
data.body: While working with highly nested directories it is highly inconvenient to expand the explorer bar just to see what file it exactly is. This will be very helpful thanks!

data.title: API to iterate over all keys
data.body:
Testing #16515:

IMO it would be good to have API that returns all currently defined (qualified) keys (from the default settings)

This currently can only be done by iterating through the configuration value tree. This is however will not work for properties like "files.exclude" that have an object as value.

data.title: gulp-tsb warning while npm installing
data.body:
I get the following warning when running `./scripts/npm.sh install`:

```
npm WARN gulp-tsb@2.0.3 requires a peer of typescript@^2.0.10 but none was installed.
```

AFAIK `typescript@2.0.10` will break our formatter: #14519.

But if `gulp-tsb@2.0.3` really requires `typescript@2.0.10` and we are not installing it... then couldn't `gulp-tsb` break?

data.title: Title doesn't refresh when we jump into other tabs
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.7.2 (7ba55c5860b152d999dda59393ca3ebeb1b5c85f, 2016-11-21T22:06:37.428Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 6.1.7601
- Extensions:

|Extension|Author|Version|
|---|---|---|
|angular2-snippets|danwahlin|1.0.5|

---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. open a file you can see application name prefixed with current open file name in Title field of VS code.
2. open another file. Title doesn't refreshes with  current opened file name.
3. jump to another window and return back name title will be refreshed.
